fields.description:
automatically created links links (suchas this: JRA-1) are absolute URL's using the BASE URL defined in the config instead of a relative link.


This doesn't work if there are multiple NATed addresses for the Jira box, as is common in extranet or corporate environments.

It would be better to limit the use of BASE URL to email only, and use relative links for web urls.
fields.summary: links in jira issues should be relative ratherr than use the BASE URL

In a shocking break with tradition, Lucene 1.4 has been released only a few months after 1.3:

http://cvs.apache.org/viewcvs.cgi/*checkout*/jakarta-lucene/CHANGES.txt?rev=1.94

fields.description:
We have several JIRA instances and they are not configured the same way.
At each time we want to move data from one to another, we have to change a lot of parameters :

- backup directory
- indexes directory
- attachments directory
- CVS base directories (we have a lot of CVS repositories !)

The best thing will be to define variables in JIRA pointing to the JIRA home directory as mentioned in JRA-1642, but also the CVS Home base directory.
In fact, today for each CVS repository, we must precise the full path, and if the servers are not configured in the same way, we must change each CVS repository information. In our case, we have 35 repositories to change !
We should use a variable that point to the local CVS Base directory. Each CVS repository should point to a folder that is a child of this base directory.
Then, we could only change the value of the CVS Base directory variable.
fields.summary: Using a variable for the CVS Home directory

fields.description:
Improve "Edit Issue" operation when issue type/project pair is only pair associated with a specific field layout.

The issue type cannot be changed in this instance - a move must be performed to change the type (and hence change the issue fields as necessary).
fields.summary: Improve "Edit Issue" when issue type cannot be changed.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-4073].
  {panel}

An extra permission is needed to allow Reporters to be able to Assign To Me, providing they are also have the Assignable User permission, but despite not having the Assign User permission.

This avoids the situation where a user can report an issue they are able to address themselves (but don't have permissions to directly assign to another user) but have to wait for the project lead (or some other appropriately permissioned user) to assign it back to the reporter.

May be addressed by some of the other related requests to do with field-level permissions in 2.7 and beyond.

h3. Workaround

A transition can be added that will allow assigning to current user, without requiring the *Assign User* [Project Permissions|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Managing+Project+Permissions]. This is explained in further detail in [Advanced workflow configuration|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Advanced+workflow+configuration].

# Edit the workflow.
# Add the transition 'Assign to Current User' and set the destination status as the current status.
# Update the Post-function to use the 'Assign to Current User'.
# Edit the condition so that it's only available for certain users, for example 'User is in Project Role'. This can also be done for other permissions, or groups. 
# Add those users to the appropriate project role, group or permission.
# Publish the workflow.

Now users with that specific permission will be able to use the 'Assign to Current User' transition.
fields.summary: Extra permission "Assign Issues To Self If Reporter"

fields.description:
Modify the "Move" operation of an issue to facilitate enterprise feature of selecting issue type and project.

The issue will need to be set to a new status if its current status is not available in the workflow of the target project and issue type.

The sub-task "move" operation must allow the user to change the sub-task type. Currently, it is not possible to move a sub-task to a different project than the one its parent issue is located in.

The "move" operation should also move all sub-tasks of the issue. If a subtask is set with an invalid status - the "move" wizard should allow the user to select a valid status for sub-tasks grouped by invalid status and current workflow.
fields.summary: Move Issue and Subtask Improvements

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-4060].
  {panel}

Our customers want to see two things in a release note:
- what has changed (done)
- what is still broken

The Release Note should have the ability to show all unresolved defects in the current release (even if they are fixed in a later release).  This would need to include defects raised against earlier (but not later) releases. 

Normally you would not want to include other types of unresolved items (eg: changes).  This could be done by choosing which unresolved issue types to include.
fields.summary: Release Note - unresolved defects

fields.description:
You need to be able to work out whether an account is active or not. The simplest way of doing this is recording in the last login time.

You then want to be able to display this in the UserBrowser (ideally, with sortable tables). You could also display it in the profile ala Confluence.

You also want to access this information via the SOAP API.
fields.summary: Record last login time for a user

fields.description:
We have a moderate-large-size jira database:
12600 issues
18700 comments

Re-indexing takes 1515 seconds (25 minutes!)

I dont know if this is expected behaviour, but its an awfully long time. If we need to re-index during the day, we are talking 1/hr downtime.
fields.summary: Re-indexing takes a very long time!

fields.description:
The standard create/edit issue form is very good for issue containing a few fields. The ordering feature in the field layout schemes is the only way to configure this form.
In large organizations, we have projects that are using 30 fields.
In this case, the standard create/edit issue form is not user friendly, because we need to scroll everytime.
What I propose is to be able to define templates for the create/edit issue form that can be associated to field layout schemes.
The administrator could then personalize the form. For instance, he could define a template to display the fields using 3 colums, or he could display them using dynamic tabs.
You could also provide 3 or 4 templates that can be reused across the field layout schemes.
For backward compatibility, the actual form should become the default template.
fields.summary: Using templates for the create/edit issue form

fields.description:
We have more than 50 custom fields and more than 10 field layout schemes in our organization.
At each time we add a new field, we need to order it in each field layout scheme. To do that, we need to click a lot of time on the ordering button.
It would be great to be able to enter directly the wanted position.
Let's say there is a field that is in position 50 and we want to move it to the position 10 in the scheme, we have to click, refresh and browse the window 40 times !
With this simple improvement, this would be done in one operation !
fields.summary: Improve the ergonomy of the field layout scheme administration

fields.description: The main problem is you can't see who deleted an Issue when sending the Delete mail.
fields.summary: Can't access Remote User in Mail Templates

fields.description: Estimate is spelled "esimate" the second time it appears in the Progress / Accuracy box.

fields.description:
If there are a large number of components (as Jira and Confluence projects do), you only see 3 at a time - which makes it a pain to scroll to the correct component.

Any chance we can make it larger? Same size as versions?
fields.summary: Components select box too small

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-4052].
  {panel}

{panel:title=21 December 2015|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#ebf2f9 | titleBGColor=#ebf2f9 | bgColor=#ffffff}
Hi everyone,

Thanks for voting and commenting on this issue. Your feedback is key to helping us understand how you use JIRA so we can continue improving your experience. We have reviewed this issue over the last few days; however there are not currently any plans to implement this suggestion.

In the meantime, please check out these plugins:
* [Configuration Manager from Botron Software|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.botronsoft.jira.configurationmanager] 
* [Project Configurator from Awnaba Software|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.awnaba.projectconfigurator.projectconfigurator]

on our Atlassian marketplace. Both of these plugins are available for the downloaded instances of JIRA and solve the use cases outlined in this requirement.


There's also another solution emerging from an Atlassian Exper Catworkx.de. You can check out the [factsheet here|https://www.catworkx.de/produkte/catWorkX%20Produkte/configuration-importer/Configuration_Importer_for_JIRA_fact_sheet.pdf]


Please remember that jira.atlassian.com is one of many inputs for the JIRA roadmap. You can [learn more about our process here|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/110373/how-does-the-jira-team-use-jira-atlassian-com].

I understand that our decision may be disappointing. Please don't hesitate to contact me if you have any questions.

Regards,
Otto Ruettinger
Principal Product Manager, JIRA
oruettinger (at) atlassian (dot) com
{panel}

*Original request description*

We really need to be able to import projects and all dependant objects (users, groups, permission schemes, notification schemes) from another JIRA instance.

We have 2 such immediate requirements at the moment.
1) We have a team using an eval copy and we want to move their issues to our production JIRA instance
2) We have a team who bought their own copy of JIRA - but now they want to move some projects to our production JIRA instance

We also have a number of other requirements
1) We have two JIRA instances - one in Paris, one in London - and we want to move some London projects to Paris.
2) Likewise, we have some NY projects - and we want NY to have its own server - which means we need a way of migrating the projects to NY at some point in the future.

NOTE: JRA-9960 is specific to workflow - if your comments are workflow related, please comment / vote on JRA-9960.
fields.summary: Import projects and all dependent objects from one Jira to another

fields.description:
I would like that if I attach a file with the same name as an existing attachment that the existing one be overwritten.  Is that possible?

Not currently, though if you would like to raise a feature request we can
consider it.  Confluence has a nice solution to this, where attachments
with the same name are 'versioned', and the latest one made available by
default.
fields.summary: Attachment Versioning

fields.description:
Our JIRA permission cheme sis based on development team groups and if a user is granted to create an issue, there is no way to restrict permission to close to the reporter.

If JIRA Enterprise version can provide this, we can consider upgrading too.
fields.summary: close permission for reporter only

fields.description:
The number of assigned issues, a person has, is not correctly shown on the project site. 

Maybe this issue is invoked by a wrong execution of a collective processing (Sammelbearbeitung).
fields.summary: Numbers of assigned issues in project site not correct

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-4048].
  {panel}

Currently Jira allows to import/export meta-data (users, groups, permissions etc.) and actual data (issues) all together.

It would be very helpful to provide more flexibility by allowing to import/export on smaller granularity level - users, groups, permissions etc.

Example:

I'd like to start and try customizing Jira on an instance separate from the one we use for evaluation purposes (do custom fields, permissions, groups etc.).

Say, I am done with customizing and would like to apply all 'metadata' changes to another instance, but only the settings, not the data itself.
fields.summary: Import/export metadata separately from data

fields.summary: The [XML] link in the single issue view does not work

fields.description: Would ne nice to have a 'Admin mode' to lock out all users except the admin.
fields.summary: Admin mode

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-4045].
  {panel}

JIRA is well-engineered, but as a heavy application generally run on a single server and doing a great deal of work to generate each information-filled page, it is not exactly "fast."  Page loads are quite reasonable, but the workflow effect of having to fully load a new page after every action makes extensive work inside JIRA much slower than it should be.

The interface is very well-designed, but even on a fast server with no load it can rarely keep up with the user because of the page-to-page latency.

Inspired by astonishingly fast web interfaces which make creative use of DHTML and client-side rendering, such as Gmail, I think it would be exceedingly useful if JIRA's interface were to evolve in this direction.

The current, indirect solution to this is to load the static pages with as much related information/form fields as possible, to reduce the frequency of loading new pages, but this has the unwanted side-effect of over-burdening many form pages with a great many large forms.

* Menus, lists (comments), etc. expand dynamically
* Forms/controls expand dynamically, a la the Gmail quick-reply/forward box
  - all pages from which one might next click an "edit" type link could have the primary linked forms embedded but hidden, so they could be opened without having to open a new page
* Dynamic view switching, as in how Gmail allows the view to switch between the current mailbox and the currently selected message without reloading the page

And if this could further be matched with quick keyboard navigation, like Gmail, the web interface would be fantastic.
fields.summary: Dynamic User Interface

fields.description:
A report from a user:

> I downloaded and installed an eval of Jira last night - great product
> BTW - I used it in my previous job.
>
> I have resolved my own issue, but thought you might be interested to
> hear about the problem, in case it is a bug you want to fix.
>
> During the setup process I created an admin user account - it allowed me
> to use mixed case for the user id  so I picked PaulHomes - a familiar
> userid for me.  Later I added a second account - but the Add User page
> required all lowercase so I picked iansutton.  I continued to login
> using PaulHomes in the JIRA login screen. All seemed fine.
>
> Today however iansutton created a project and I was unable to browse it
> even though I was in the jira-users, jira-administrators and
> jira-developers groups.  It got weirder when I created a new project as
> the lead - although I was able to create the project and the iansutton
> account could browse it I could not - I still able to administer the
> site though.
>
> Eventually it clicked and I logged out and logged in again using
> paulhomes (same account - different case).  I was able to browse and
> administer.  If I logged in using PaulHomes - I could only administer.
>
> Perhaps it would be good if you were able to prevent the initial mixed
> case user account in the setup process, disallow non-lowercase logins or
> convert the userid to lowercase during the login process.
fields.summary: Mixed case usernames can be created in the setup wizard

fields.description:
Comments are appearing in issue updated, attachment created, and link created emails for people who should not see them due to their comment level.  I first noticed this today when I got an update email from jira.atlassian.com that included a comment that I couldn't see once I opened the issue.

The issue is caused by the IssueUpdater used by subclasses of AbstractIssueUpdateAction.  We've patched it on our side, the specific problem is that DefaultIssueUpdater is not setting an "eventsource" on the params Map when dispatching the event...see the last line in DefaultIssueUpdater.  MailingListCompiler ignores the comment level if the eventsource is null, and therefore the comment is included in all emails.
fields.summary: Comment level ignored in certain notifications

fields.description:
We have associated several CVS repositories to each JIRA project, and it seems that JIRA is only using the first repository to detect commits.
A warning is printed to the JIRA output that's says something like that : "3 CVS repositories are associated to this project : returning the first one"
I suppose it confirms the fact that JIRA can detect commits only using the first associated CVS repository.
Consequently, I think it's a bug : why can we associate multiple CVS repositories per project if JIRA uses only the first one ?

We are very interesting in having a quick fix for this.
fields.summary: Multiple CVS repositories associated to one project doesn't work

fields.description: FishEye rocks & is the best way of viewing/working with CVS. Can we get JIRA-CVS integration to support it please? The URLs are just a little different

For example if you're viewing page 2 of 3 pages of filter results, bulk edit all issues only shows you the issues on pages 2 and 3, not 1-3.

fields.description:
Steps:
* Change group membership in User > Edit Groups (either add or remove)
* Click on left side menu headings to expand/contract a menu category

Expected result:
Page refreshes with selected menu newly open or closed, but otherwise essentially unchanged.

Result:
Page refreshes with the following error:
----
Form Errors:
User does not exist

<< Return to viewing user ''
----
and no user selected.  It appears that the user variable gets replaced by an emptystring or a broken escape string or something similar, as instead of saying 'Return to viewing user "<user>"' it says 'Return to viewing user "' (note the single-quote).

Frst discovered when initially adding confluence-users and confluence-administrators, per http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/How+to+delegate+user+management+in+Confluence+to+JIRA, but it also happens when changing the built-in (and still-unchanged, in my new trial install) groups, jira-*.
fields.summary: In-place refresh of "Edit User Groups" page causes "User does not exist" error

fields.description:
Hi,

What I'd like to see is the following. When I'm working in Jira I got to the issue navigator (say for example issues for me). Most of the time I click on an issue, update it, comment it whatever and then I want to go back to my list of issues. The way I work now is pushing the back button several times to go to the list. What I do want is to go back directly to my issuenavigator.

So what I suggest is some kind of breadcrum to be able to select the issue navigator directly (click it) and go back to that list.

Regards,

Pim van Wetten
fields.summary: Breadcrum for navigation

Possibility to hide email adresses from users when sending group email with the admin option 'send e-mail'.
Now all emailadresses are listed in the To: field. This is not always desirable. So option to hide with BCC for instance would be nice.

Changes deltas in history

fields.description: Would love to be able to create a project template with all of the standard tracking issues I use as well as the documents I associate with  a new project.  Then when I need to start a new project I can just clone  the template.
fields.summary: Clone Project

fields.description:
So in installations with many users I am not sure if there is a good way to limit the user *and* project pull-down list so that those users in certain department of the organization can only see those users and projects in their department.  Maybe this can already be accomplished through permissions and I just haven't groked it yet? <--quite possible!  

The functionality I would like to see, though, would be something like this:

There would be a mechanism for assigning a user a home department.  Then ,in a project, you build a team (even with users from different department).

However, only users from the project team will be listed in the drop-down lists for issues creation, etc..

Also when users log into the system on their home they would only see projects associated with their home department.
fields.summary: Business unit: a method for organizing users and projects

fields.description: Would love to be able to bulk create issues, particularly handy when creating new projects.
fields.summary: Bulk create issues

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-4026].
  {panel}

In several cases, operations require a little dialog, like a one minute question, for example, to confirm the deletion of a component or of a group inside a permission.

Some web-app do this in a pop-up... why does Jira not do so ?

Maybe it's bad style to use these pop-ups, I agree... but there's one advantage you expect of them that Jira should still provide: scroll to the position where I pressed the link.
It would be simple to do so if everything is a form and the scroll position can be read at time of sending the request and be re-used with an internal link or with some JS... clearly, it might affect some browsers only... ah well.

paul
fields.summary: Scroll to position where we were
Creating a user in group

fields.summary: JIRA setup page 1 of 3 clears some field.

fields.description: Oh, I would love to be able to find all resolved cases and do a "group close" on them all in one shot! :-)
fields.summary: Would love to have a 'group close' function!

fields.description:
This strikes us as a bug, maybe you don't agree. Thought I'd report it.

I have an issue assigned to 'me' and I 'start progress' on it. Then, someone comes along as re-assigns it to 'fred'. The issue remains in progress for 'me' and Fred cannot change this, or start progress for himself.

It seems to me that in the ideal world, multiple people could have an issue in progress. But if that fails, then when it is re-assigned perhaps 1) Fred should have permission to stop progress by someone else or 2) the system should automatically do this...

As it is, Fred has to send an email to 'me' asking me to 'stop progress' so that he can start...
fields.summary: Progress cannot be stopped on re-assigned issue

fields.description:
A week ago, we made our JIRA instance available on a public address (still private). It is still running on the same server, but before we accessed it using an internal address like http://pi-ds-002:8080 and now we use a public address. We made some changes to the proxy and the firewall and all seemed to work fine. Ofcourse, we also changed the "Base URL" setting in JIRA.

Since then, some weirdness has occurred: sometimes a developer updates an issue and we notice that another developer doesn't see the change. Also, when linking two issues, we see the link added in one issue, but not in the other. 

These problems occur very little, and they also go away after flushing the cache and re-indexing JIRA. The strange thing is that we never had these problems before we changed the "Base URL" setting. I don't whether it is at all possible that these are related, but I get a little itchy from this kind of weird behaviour.
fields.summary: Proxying Jira 2.6 with a Microsoft ISA server requires 'Cache objects that have an unspecified last modification time' of Cache Configuration Properties to be Unchecked

fields.description:
JIRA now has the ability for an admin to send a message to a group of users. This apparently fails if one email address is incorrect:

> When attempting to send an email to a jira group, I get an error 'FAILED to send email to the list of users displayed below.' & 'Form Errors:  The error was: Illegal address'. 
> 
> Ok, but /which/ address? Also nothing in the log file indicating the address that was invalid. Is this a response from the smpt server? If so, it would better if jira sent the email to each address individually when the bulk send fails so we can at last figure out which email is bad. 
> 
> Also, no messages were sent -- even to the addresses that are correct.
fields.summary: One bad email address causes group send to fail

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-4016].
  {panel}

Version numbers are very difficult to work with, and provide poor semantics.

Adding a new version requires multiple steps: add the version, schedule the version. This should be single step. Maybe by selecting the before/after existing version when adding. (Often we are adding versions to our production branch, but the development branch version has already been created and should remain the last version.

Well, if version were richer in semantics, the above would be a non-issue. Often we have version like:

10.0
10.1
10.2
11.0
11.1

But jira sees these as only text strings. The ability to treat version hierarchically would be very helpful:

10     (where this represents a major version)
.10.0  (these reprent minor versions, or patches)
.10.1
.10.2

If this semantic was part of the model, reordering would not be required. Of course, this semantic would need to be configurable as I'm sure some users really do want just text values. But I suspect most really use numbers as above.

The concept of released/non-released seems only to be manifest in the selection lists when selecting versions. We would like to place restrictions on what affects-versions can be assigned to a [new] issue. For example, in our process, it never makes sense for a non-developer (eg, group jira-developer) to assing a version to a non-released version. Our users/tests are always assigning issues non-sensical versions (ie, a bug against a version that has not been deployed). 

Extending the released/non-released to versions in development/test/production would be very helpful. Of course, this is just one example of assinging meta-data to the version. Others will want other values for the, say, version state. Some will want other meta-data, like comments associated with a version. But mainly we are looking for the ability to control the workflow based on the version meta-data.

The simple stringness of version makes it difficult to create a ant-task that can bounce version numbers are part of a deployment. I've looked into the code, and yes, it would not be too hard manipulate the versions. But it would require parsing and such. If version had first-class semantics, statements such as: "Create the next version the v10 line". If v10.4 was the current last version, v10.5 would be created. And if v11.x already existed, v10.5. would be scheduled prior to any v11's. 

Again, this makes assumptions about the meaning of version. I know you wanted to leave much flexibility. Maybe some kind of plugin framework that allows for incorporating version semantics...
fields.summary: Rich semantics for version numbers

fields.description: I'd like to be able to sort, so I can more easily select the issues I want to affect. It would also be nice to be able to filter this list...
fields.summary: allow sorting of issues in the bulk operation screen

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:
1.) Have a Bugzilla instance with a bunch of bugs entered. Mine had ~4800.
2.) Walk through JIRA's Bugzilla Importer.
When you click the final "Import" button, you will see the progressbar fill a bit, then Safari will put up a "could not load page after trying for 60 seconds" dialog.

Expected behavior:
I expected the browser to wait until the import had finished and then give some results.
fields.summary: Bugzilla import results page times out when using Safari browser

fields.description:
Bugzilla normally doesn't allow empty summaries to be entered, but in this case, a custom import from another database entered some. When the JIRA-Bugzilla importer hit these records, the importer bailed with a "returning empty set" in catalina.out. Every previous record had to then be rescanned each import attempt to see if it needed to be imported.

Steps to reproduce:
1.) Have a Bugzilla instance that contains bugs with emtpy summaries (hacking of Bugzilla may be necessary - check post_bug.cgi?)
2.) Walk through JIRA's Bugzilla Importer, and import your Bugzilla containing the "broken" bugs.
You'll see the importer stop. The workaround is of course delete those records manually from the Bugzilla tables manually.

Expected behavior:
A warning in catalina.out should be sufficient and import should proceed.
fields.summary: Bugzilla importer doesn't handle NULL values for summaries gracefully

fields.description:
USE CASE:
Use this signature for versioning: 1.1.1
Create an issue with "Fix for Version(s)" = 1.1.1.
Export a search result containing this issue and with active column "Fix for Version" to Excel.

EXPECTED:
In Excel, all columns retain the original format.

REAL:
The "Fix for Version(s)" column in the Excel document shows "01.01.2001", and reformatting (e.g. to Standard format") results in 36892.

NOTE:
A version like 1.0.0 does fine when exported to Excel.
fields.summary: Excel export: Column "Fix for Version(s)" is converted to Date format

fields.description:
When an issue creation fails because the description field exceeds the maximum allowed (4983 bytes -- per the log file) a java.lang.reflect.UndeclaredThrowableException exception is raised.  This does not mean anything to the user.

It would be nice if the low level SQL exception were caught and wrapped to present the user with a friendly message that would suggest a recourse.
fields.summary: More useful error message required

fields.description:
The projects portlet on the dashboard that displays detailed project information includes a report of "Open Issues: (By Priority)".  This is presented as a color-coded bar.  The numbers however are not accurate.
 
I have, for example, a project for which the portlet reports 7 major issues.  However, clicking on that part of the bar surfaces only 2 issues.  Digging deeper I found that there are indeed 7 major issues for the project -- however only 2 of them are in the Open state.
 
So, shouldn't the bar on the portlet report just 2 issues?  The label after all indicates that the bar represents open issues.
fields.summary: Incorrect Issue totals on project portlet

fields.description:
I want to add a filter where I can see the issues that I reported but that are not assigned to me and that are still unresolved.

Problem : You can't select not current user from the assignee box.

Solution : It's just reversing the one of assigned to current user, so I guess it's not a big thing to ask for.

But it would be a great help to me and probably to lots of other users.
fields.summary: I want to see the issues reported by me but not assigned to me

fields.description: It would be very useful and probably trivial to add the ability to add a property to the Project Table portlet to filter the projects displayed by category.
fields.summary: Project table dashboard portlet should support filtering by category

fields.description:
The workflow integrity checker will need to determine a suitable default workflow id/step from the current workflow of an issue during the correction process.

At present - the workflow checker is hardcoded to set the invalid issue to workflow step/id 6 - which may not exist in a custom workflow.
fields.summary: Workflow Integrity Checker should handle custom statuses/workflows.

fields.description:
While trying out JIRA we are having a problem trying to attach files to an issue and also cannot add screenshots to an issue.

Screenshots attached
fields.summary: Cannot attach file to issue

 was saved as
"http://confluence.atlassian.com/pages/viewpage.action"
you can see what i'm talking in CONF-1504.

fields.description:
The time to add a user to a group depends heaviliy on the number of issues in the system. This is scary, the operation is already painfully slow and will only get slower and slower over time. 

Intuitively one would expect that adding a group to a user is a constant time operation (basically add one line in a link table).

Here is a profile for adding a group to a user. It seems that a complete reindexing is performed, and that it is even done multiple times.

fields.description: We want to be able to register in a custom field the date and time of some events that are not in JIRA (e.g. the moment that we sent the analysis to the customer). The problem is that there is only a date data type, but not a date & time type. In those cases we need to be able to record the time (HH:MM). Can this be added?
fields.summary: Add a timestamp (date & time) custom field type

fields.description:
When requesting Release Notes from JIRA, the generated overview contains all issues for the specified version regardless their status or resolution. Since the releasenotes don't contain any further information like status or resolution, it is not clear what has been fixed in a release.

Normally one would, ofcourse, move all open issues to another version, but in our case we do a lot of builds of our "platform" which is then given to the various other teams that depend on it. So before we do a formal release, a lot of builds have been taken place and we would like to include a list of things that have been changed and have that one grow up to the point of the first actual release. 

So, I would like to be able to generate releasenotes for unreleased versions (typically a branch version like 1.8) and have either a list of things that have been closed or resolved, OR a list of issues including their status and resolution.
fields.summary: Releasenotes show all issues

fields.description: It would be useful if JIRA could display 'virtual' fields like 'closed by', 'last commenter', 'last comment' 'votes', 'time estimate', 'remaining time' etc. in Issue Navigator page and users can export this info to MS Excel
fields.summary: Adding virtual fields in Issue Navigator field
jira should be more pronounceable by americans

fields.description:
If there is a link to an issue that is not visible (perhaps because it is in another project invisible to the current user), the "Issue Links:" box will still appear, even the "Duplicate" and "This issue is duplicated by:", but no link to the invisible issue.  This looks buggy to a user that doesn't know why it's happening.

A similar issue occurs when an issue that is linked to is deleted.  The "Issue Links" box still appears on the issue linking to the deleted one, but with no links.  (it does however still have the old heading)  To reproduce: simply link two tasks, delete one, and view the remaining task.
fields.summary: Issue Links box appears when there are no visible links

fields.description:
In some situations we frequently have issues that get closed and re-opened - sometimes the same issue gets re-opened many times.

This obviously indicates a problem - but there is no easy way to see a report of the issues and the number of times they have been re-opened.

It would be good if this statistic was displayed (and available in the excel export).
fields.summary: Display the number of times an issue has been re-opened in the issue navigator.

Updater: Keith Brophy (mailto:keith@atlassian.com)
Date: Tue, 29 Jun 2004 9:03 PM
Changes: Attachment changed to screen-shot.jpg
--------------------------------------------------------

fields.description:
We are evaluating JIRA. I created a user and assigned only "jira-develpers" group to it. After that, the user cannot login -- JIRA tells that login or password are incorrect. I am sure I do not forget the password because when I assign jira-users group to this same user as well, I can login all right.

The problem is well repeatable.

I use the Default Permission Scheme. I do not see "log in" permission in the list of permissions  but even if the behavior is this by design, I believe, user must have more information about why the access is denied because it authenticates itself correctly.
fields.summary: Change error message when user does not have global USE permission

fields.description:
Currently, creating a sub-issue/parent-issue link between two tasks only sets a descriptive link with a string on each task. This is a major problem on our project where we often need to divide issues into subissues, but still retain valid time tracking.

Its important to be able to view all super-tasks of a version, and see how well they have progressed without being bogged down by the details of the subissues.

At the same time it is important to use estimates for the subissues themselves.

Only two approaches are possible (as I see it) in Jira 2.6.1:

1. Let the super-issue reflect the time needed to wrap things up, after the sub-issues are complete. The problem is that one can't view all supertasks to get an estimate of version completion.

2. Let the super-issue-estimate be the sum of all sub-issue-estimates. This causes two problems: Developers have to log work twice; once in the subissue, and once in the superissue, and also, this causes wrong numbers in the time tracking of a version, since all estimates are doubled (both in super-issue and sub-issue)

Neither of these solutions are very usable, so a harder link between tasks is needed, perhaps enabling a hierarchy of tasks.
fields.summary: Enable time-estimation links between issue and sub-issues.
